title: New York State Route 37B
text:
New York State Route 37B (NY 37B) is an east–west <a href="state%20highway">state highway</a> located in <a href="St.%20Lawrence%20County%2C%20New%20York">St. Lawrence County, New York</a>, in the United States. It serves as a <a href="business%20route">business route</a> of <a href="New%20York%20State%20Route%2037">NY 37</a> through the <a href="Massena%20%28village%29%2C%20New%20York">village of Massena</a>. While NY 37B enters the village, NY 37 bypasses it to the south. The western terminus of the route is at an intersection with NY 37 in the town of <a href="Louisville%2C%20New%20York">Louisville</a>. Its eastern terminus is at a junction with NY 37 just east of the village limits in the <a href="Massena%20%28town%29%2C%20New%20York">town of Massena</a>. NY 37B intersects North Main Street, a state-maintained northward extension of <a href="New%20York%20State%20Route%20420">NY 420</a>, in Massena's central district.
The origins of NY 37B date back to the early 20th century when the <a href="New%20York%20State%20Legislature">New York State Legislature</a> created Route 32, an unsigned <a href="legislative%20route">legislative route</a> extending from North Lawrence to <a href="Ogdensburg%2C%20New%20York">Ogdensburg</a> via Massena. From <a href="Waddington%20%28village%29%2C%20New%20York">Waddington</a> to Massena, Route 32 followed River Road and Town Line Road. This portion of the route became part of <a href="New%20York%20State%20Route%203">NY 3</a> in 1924. In the <a href="1930%20state%20highway%20renumbering%20%28New%20York%29">1930 renumbering of state highways in New York</a>, the Waddington–Massena segment of NY 3 became NY 37B. The route was extended east into Massena in the 1950s after NY 37 was realigned to follow a new bypass around the village.
Most of NY 37B west of Massena ran through a low-lying area along the <a href="St.%20Lawrence%20River">St. Lawrence River</a>. In 1958, this area was permanently indundated as part of the <a href="St.%20Lawrence%20Seaway">St. Lawrence Seaway</a>'s construction. As a result, NY 37B was rerouted to follow a new roadway along the fringe of <a href="Lake%20St.%20Lawrence">Lake St. Lawrence</a> to meet NY 37 in Louisville Corner. A connector between NY 37 and NY 37B in Louisville was designated as <a href="New%20York%20State%20Route%20131">NY 131</a> by 1960. The alignments of NY 37B and NY 131 west of Massena were swapped , placing NY 37B on its modern alignment.
Route description.
NY 37B begins at an intersection with its parent route, <a href="New%20York%20State%20Route%2037">NY 37</a>, in the town of <a href="Louisville%2C%20New%20York">Louisville</a>. The route heads to the northeast, paralleling the <a href="Grasse%20River">Grasse River</a> as it passes a small number of homes and businesses located in the otherwise rural town. There are small patches of forested areas along the way to the <a href="Massena%20%28village%29%2C%20New%20York">Massena village</a> line (and the town's line of the same name), where it intersects with Town Line Road (<a href="County%20Route%2043%20%28St.%20Lawrence%20County%2C%20New%20York%29">County Route 43</a>). Once in Massena, the amount of development along the highway begins to increase. NY 37B, now known as Maple Street, continues northeast through Massena for three blocks before veering eastward upon passing Massena Memorial Hospital.
In the center of Massena, NY 37B intersects North Main Street, which connects to <a href="New%20York%20State%20Route%20420">NY 420</a> south of the village. The portion of Main Street between NY 420 and NY 37B is maintained by the <a href="New%20York%20State%20Department%20of%20Transportation">New York State Department of Transportation</a> as NY 970B, an unsigned <a href="reference%20route%20%28New%20York%29">reference route</a>. Past North Main Street, NY 37B follows Maple Street southeast to Center Street. The route merges with Center Street and becomes a <a href="divided%20highway">divided highway</a> as it connects to Willow Street by way of an interchange and intersects an eastward extension of Center Street.
NY 37B turns south at the interchange, becoming Parker Avenue and crossing over the Grasse River to meet East Orvis Street on the southern riverbank. Here, the route turns east to follow East Orvis Street northeastward through the residential and commercial areas that comprise southeastern Massena. At the <a href="Massena%20%28village%29%2C%20New%20York">Massena village</a> line, East Orvis Street becomes Highland Road, a name NY 37B retains for a short distance eastward to a junction with NY 37 (St. Regis Boulevard). Although Highland Road continues through the intersection, NY 37B ends at the junction.
History.
In 1908, the <a href="New%20York%20State%20Legislature">New York State Legislature</a> created Route 32, an unsigned <a href="legislative%20route">legislative route</a> extending from North Lawrence to <a href="Ogdensburg%2C%20New%20York">Ogdensburg</a> via Winthrop and <a href="Massena%20%28village%29%2C%20New%20York">Massena</a>. It entered Massena on what is now <a href="New%20York%20State%20Route%20420">NY 420</a> and followed Main Street and Maple Street through the village. West of Massena, the highway was routed on Town Line Road and River Road to a junction east of <a href="Waddington%20%28village%29%2C%20New%20York">Waddington</a>, where Route 32 continued west on modern <a href="New%20York%20State%20Route%2037">NY 37</a> to Waddington. When state highways in <a href="New%20York%20%28state%29">New York</a> were first posted in 1924, the portion of Route 32 between Waddington and Massena became part of <a href="New%20York%20State%20Route%203">NY 3</a>, a highway extending across the width of the state.
The segment of NY 3 east of <a href="Watertown%20%28city%29%2C%20New%20York">Watertown</a> was rerouted as part of the <a href="1930%20state%20highway%20renumbering%20%28New%20York%29">1930 renumbering of state highways in New York</a> to largely follow its modern alignment between Watertown and <a href="Plattsburgh%20%28city%29%2C%20New%20York">Plattsburgh</a>. Most of NY 3's former alignment along the <a href="St.%20Lawrence%20River">St. Lawrence River</a> from <a href="Alexandria%20Bay%2C%20New%20York">Alexandria Bay</a> to <a href="Hogansburg%2C%20New%20York">Hogansburg</a> became part of the new <a href="New%20York%20State%20Route%2037">NY 37</a>; however, from Waddington to Massena, NY 37 used a more inland routing. As a result, the former routing of NY 3 between the two villages became NY 37B instead. In the mid-to-late 1950s, NY 37 was rerouted to follow a new bypass around the southern edge of Massena. Following its completion, NY 37B was extended eastward along NY 37's former routing on Maple Street, Parker Avenue, and Orvis Street to meet the bypass east of the village.
In the 1950s, construction began on the <a href="St.%20Lawrence%20Seaway">St. Lawrence Seaway</a>, a system of canals and locks that would make the St. Lawrence River suitable for shipping. As part of the seaway's construction, a low-lying area in <a href="Ontario">Ontario</a> and New York between Waddington, New York, and <a href="Cornwall%2C%20Ontario">Cornwall, Ontario</a>, would be inundated with water in order to create a navigable channel through the <a href="Long%20Sault">Long Sault</a> rapids and to allow hydroelectric stations to be established immediately upriver from Massena and Cornwall. Much of NY 37B was located within the flood-prone region due to its proximity to the river. On July 1, 1958, the intentional flooding was carried out via the destruction of a <a href="cofferdam">cofferdam</a> upstream, creating what is now known as <a href="Lake%20St.%20Lawrence">Lake St. Lawrence</a> and inundating the majority of NY 37B west of Massena.
Following the destruction of the majority of NY 37B, the route was realigned west of Massena to follow a new riverside roadway to the <a href="hamlet%20%28New%20York%29">hamlet</a> of Louisville Corner, where it came to an end at NY 37. The remainder of NY 37B along the Massena–<a href="Louisville%2C%20New%20York">Louisville</a> town line road and in Massena was unchanged. By 1960, a connector between NY 37 in Louisville and NY 37B and Massena utilizing NY 37's former routing west of the village was designated as <a href="New%20York%20State%20Route%20131">NY 131</a>. The alignments of NY 37B and NY 131 west of the Maple Street / Town Line Road intersection were flipped , placing NY 131 on the riverside and town line roads and NY 37B on NY 37's former routing into Massena.
